citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Enclosures housing birds such as swans, flamingos, ducks, chickens, pigeons, and peafowl, have a moderate
accumulation of excreta and other organic waste material present. Although the facility currently has a cleaning schedule
in place for the enclosures, including perches, den boxes, and water features, the cleaning intervals are not sufficient to
maintain the enclosures as required. Accumulations of excreta and waste products may increase disease hazards to
animal areas. Excreta and food waste must be removed from primary enclosures and from under and around primary
enclosures as often as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the
birds contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The water receptacles in two chicken enclosures have a moderate accumulation of dirt and other organic material
present. Although there were other water sources available to the chickens, this does not follow husbandry standards and
may increase disease hazards to animal areas. Water receptacles for birds must be sanitized as often as necessary to
prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 12/8/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
